title-group.article-title: Comparison Between Local and General Anesthesia for Carotid Endarterectomy: Early and Late Results

abstract.p: Background: The aim of this retrospective study was to compare the results between general and local anesthesia (LA) for carotid endarterectomy (CEA). Methods: Three hundred and twenty-nine patients in whom 365 CEA procedures were performed between January 1990 and September 2001, were included in this study. Results: Operation time, shunt usage rates, hospitalization time (P < .0001), and permanent stroke rates (P < .05) were significantly lower in group with LA. For long-term period (121.3 ± 37.45 vs 98.6 ± 28.98 months), no significant difference was observed in these 2 group with respect to restenosis rates, neurological events, and deaths. Conclusions: Despite the lack of significant difference between LA and general anesthesia in terms of restenosis, neurological events, and death in the long-term period; LA is more preferable due its associated advantages including availability of testing the consciousness of the patients by direct contact, reduced use of shunts, shorter hospitalization periods, and less prevalence of permanent stroke in the short-term period.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
One of the main causes of stroke is stenosis of the carotid arteries. The value of carotid endarterectomy (CEA) has been emphasized in several controlled, randomized studies. 1
–6 Carotid endarterectomy was first described 7 in 1950s and implemented widely in the 1960s and 1970s to prevent stroke. However, some major operative complications such as stroke or even death diminished the success of this procedure. In CEA, there are 2 options for anesthesia administration, namely local or general anesthesia (GA). The GA option provides the advantages of optimal positioning of the patient, better control of oxygenation and ventilation, adequate cerebral perfusion pressure without increasing the oxygen need of myocardium, lower cerebral metabolic rate, lower neuronal activity without leading to hypotension, and prevention of cerebral edema by decreasing intracranial pressure. 8
–12 However, its major disadvantage is the inadequate control of cerebral perfusion pressure during cross clamping There are also many specific problems despite numerous monitoring techniques. Direct neurological monitoring of the awake patient eliminates the necessity for equipment for that purpose. Therefore, there is an increasing interest in using regional anesthesia. In the present study, our aim was to compare the effects of local (LA) and GA for CEA on early and long-term outcomes.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: The preoperative, perioperative, and 30-day postoperative results of patients undergoing CEA under LA or GA were published 13 in 2003. In the current study, the long-term results of the same population were added and the study was evaluated anew. Approval of this study was obtained from the Research Ethics Board. Three hundred and twenty-nine patients in whom 365 CEA procedures were performed between January 1990 and September 2001, were included in the present study. The same surgical team performed the operations. At the beginning, GA was mostly used for CEA, later GA substituted with LA (GA only used for CEA if the patient refused LA). The patients included were divided into 2 groups as group 1 in which CEA was performed under GA (barbiturates and volatile agents) and group 2 in which CEA was performed under LA (deep and superficial cervical blockage with bupivacain, intravenous sedatives, and anxiolytics). All patients underwent color Doppler ultrasonography, magnetic resonance or conventional angiography, or both to determine preoperative stenosis of the carotid and vertebral arteries. Stump pressures of patients in group 1 were measured and a routine shunting (Pruitt-Inahara shunt) was performed in those with stump pressures of <50 mm Hg. In Group 2, shunt indication was assessed by the patient’s speech function. In case of clamping intolerance, a Pruitt-Inahara shunt was positioned. Following CEA procedures, the arteries were sutured with running 6.0 prolene, and Dacron patch plasty was performed in arteries with a diameter <4 mm. In both groups, an intraoperative duplex scan before the closure of the surgical incision was performed to check the perviousness of carotid vessels. Blood pressure was recorded directly using a radial artery catheter. Preoperative antiplatelet and statin treatment was continued during the operative and postoperative period.

Patients were followed-up by surgeons or, if needed, by specialized neurologists during the first 30 days postoperatively. Neurological events as well as other events, including deaths, were recorded. Subsequently, vascular structures of all patients were evaluated by their surgeons or specialized neurologists at 6-month intervals initially and later annually. Carotid and vertebral arteries were evaluated via Doppler ultrasonography and stenoses ≥70% were considered to be significant. Recurrent stenosis determined by experienced radiologists was confirmed by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) angiography, computed tomography (CT) angiography, digital subtraction angiography (DSA), or conventional angiography. Complications observed during the follow-up period such as transient ischemic attack (TIA), transient ischemic neurologic deficit (TIND), and permanent stroke were recorded. Patient information regarding death that did not occur in our center was obtained from local specialists.

The statistical analysis was performed using the Statistical Program for Social Sciences (SPSS, Inc, Chicago, Illinois). Short-term results of groups were compared using unpaired t test, Student t test, and 2-sided P value. A P value <.05 was considered statistically significant.

Kaplan-Meier curves were used to plot cumulative 11-year survival, ipsilateral stroke-free survival, and stenosis-free survival rates. The log-rank test was used to determine statistical significance from the Kaplan-Meier curves. A P value <.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 165 CEA procedures (45.6%) were performed on 150 patients (45.2%; mean age 64.3 years) in group 1 and 200 CEA procedures (54.8%) were performed on 179 patients (54.4%; mean age 66.1 years) in group 2. The patients’ characteristics at baseline are presented in Table 1 . When baseline data of 2 groups were compared, there were no significant differences between the 2 groups.

sec.title: Summary of Outcomes Within 30 Days of Surgery
sec.p: The prevalence of peroperative hypertension was lower in group 1 (P < .0001); however, the use of intraoperative antihypertensive medications was similar in both groups. The duration of operation, cross-clamping time, and duration of hospitalization were shorter and use of shunts was lower in group 2 (P < .0001). Patches were used in 15 patients in group 1 and in 14 patients in group 2; there was no significant difference between the groups with regard to the use of patches (Table 2 ).

sec.p: Mortality and morbidity (transient ischemic attack, myocardial infarction [MI], cranial nerve injury, wound infection, and hematoma) rates were similar in both groups, with the exception of permanent stroke rates. Our surgical complications included nerve injuries (n = 2 vs n = 1), wound infection (n = 1 vs n = 1) and (n = 1 vs n = 2) neck hematomas requiring surgical evacuation, with no further sequelae. The patients in group 1 had significantly higher permanent stroke rate compared to those in group 2 (n = 12 vs n = 2; P < .05). We observed that all the strokes seen after CEA diagnosed by MRI were ipsilateral. Myocardial infarction was the reason for death in both groups. Deaths (n = 2 vs n = 1) were attributable to MI in both groups. There were no cases of occlusion or restenosis within the first 30 days (Table 2).

sec.title: Late Outcomes
sec.p: Average duration of follow-up was 121.3 ± 37.45 months (range 48-192) in group 1 and 98.6 ± 28.98 months (range 49-168) in group 2.

Restenosis developed in 11 patients in group 1 and 10 patients in group 2. The incisions of all patients who experienced restenosis were closed primarily. There were no cases of occlusion in either group. Among the patients who developed restenosis, only 1 patient in group 1 and 2 patients in group 2 were symptomatic. All 3 of these patients were reoperated using Dacron patches. Their symptoms disappeared after reoperation.

Eleven patients from group 1 and 12 patients from group 2 died during the follow-up period. The causes of deaths in group 1 were MI (n = 6), cancer (n = 2), renal failure (n = 1), stroke (n = 1), and heart failure (n = 1); and in Group 2, MI (n = 7), cancer (n = 1), renal failure (n = 1), stroke (n = 2), and unknown (n = 1).

Ipsilateral stroke occurred in 5 patients in group 1 and in 6 patients in group 2. In group 1, the stroke was fatal in 1 patient, permanent in 2 patients, and temporary in 2 patients. In group 2, the stroke was fatal in 2 patients, permanent in 1 patient, and temporary in 3 patients. Carotid arteries were found patent in all patients with stroke but we were unable to get information about the status of carotid arteries for the cases with fatal stroke. No signs of stenosis were noted during earlier evaluations of the patients with fatal stroke. As their relatives did not give consent for autopsy, we were not able to evaluate the carotid arteries of these patients.

sec.title: Statistical Comparison of Late Outcomes
sec.p: In group 1, restenosis occurred in 1 patient at 12 months, 2 patients at 24 months, 2 patients at 48 months, 1 patient at 60 months, 2 patients at 84 months, 1 patient at 96 months, and 2 patients at 108 months. In group 2, restenosis occurred in 2 patients at 24 months, 2 patients at 36 months, 1 patient at 48 months, 1 patient at 72 months, 2 patients at 84 months, and 2 patients at 96 months. No significant difference was observed between groups 1 and 2 with respect to the restenosis-free survival rates (P = .629; Figure 1 ).

sec.p: There was no significant difference between groups 1 and 2 with respect to the overall survival rates (P = .998; Figure 2 ). In group 1, 1 patient died at 48 months, 2 patients at 60 months, 2 patients at 72 months, 4 patients at 84 months, 1 patient at 96 months, and 1 patient at 108 months. In group 2, 2 patients died at 36 months, 2 patients at 48 months, 3 patients at 60 months, 1 patient at 72 months, 2 patients at 84 months, and 2 patients at 96 months.

caption.p: The overall survival rates of the study groups.

sec.p: No significant difference was noted between groups 1 and 2 with respect to the ipsilateral stroke-free survival rates (P = .984; Figure 3 ). In group 1, there were 2 patients with stroke at 24 months, 1 patient at 48 months, 1 patient at 60 months, and 1 patient at 84 months. In group 2, there was 1 patient with stroke at 24 months, 1 patient at 36 months, 1 patient at 48 months, 2 patients at 60 months, and 1 patient at 84 months.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Anesthesiologic management for CEA was discussed in more than 500 publications during the last 30 years. However, it is still controversial and the number of randomized, controlled studies comparing LA and GA in CEA is inadequate. 14,15 The choice of anesthesia method depends on each center’s experience. We are using both GA and LA at our center.

The most serious complications of CEA are brain damage related to cross-clamping and perioperative cardiovascular events. In order to prevent these complications, various techniques including electroencephalography, somatosensory-evoked potentials, measurement of jugular bulb oxygen saturation (SjO2), plasma adenosine concentration in the jugular vein, cerebral oximetry (rSO2), stump pressure monitoring, and sonographic measurement of middle cerebral artery blood flow velocity are used. However, many of these techniques are not readily available in the operating room, and since false-positive or false-negative results are relatively high, reliability is controversial, as well. 16 One of the most important advantages of CEA performed under LA is thought to be the monitoring of the awake patient. As a result, LA has become the favored option in recent years and its benefits in CEA have been demonstrated in many studies.

A recent Cochrane Database Systemic Review in 2009 showed that there was no evidence of a reduction in operative strokes (2.7% for GA vs 2.7% for LA, P = .99), but the use of LA was associated with a significant reduction in the 30-day perioperative local hemorrhage (odds ratio [OR] of 0.30, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.12-0.77) in meta-analysis of 9 randomized studies and showed that the use of LA was associated with significant reductions in the risk of 30-day perioperative stroke, death, MI, and pulmonary complication in meta-analysis of the nonrandomized studies. 17 According the authors’ conclusion there is insufficient evidence from randomized trials comparing CEA performed under LA and GA, and nonrandomized studies suggest potential benefits with the use of LA. Chiesa et al 18 administered locoregional anesthesia in 96% of 5425 CEA operations and reported the prevalence of perioperative mortality as 0.37% and neurological morbidity as 1.31%. Assadian et al 19 reported a 30-day mortality rate of 0.2% and stroke rate of 2.2% in 1355 CEA operations that were performed with locoregional anesthesia. Halm et al 20 reported that LA might reduce the risk of death and stroke in their study. In our previously published study we specified that LA decreases the need for shunting, shortens the duration of surgery and hospitalization, and lowers the rate of permanent stroke compared with GA within 30 days. 13

The strongest level 1 evidence was recently published in the General Anesthesia vs Local Anesthesia for Carotid Surgery (GALA) trial. 21 The GALA trial did not show a difference in the primary outcome (postoperative stroke, MI, or death between randomization and 30 days after anesthesia) between patients undergoing CEA under LA versus GA. There was no difference in postoperative quality-of-life data collected 4 to 6 weeks after surgery. Similarly, there was no definite evidence that the type of anesthesia affects the length of hospital stay. But some authors brought serious criticisms to this study. According to Joanne Guay, 22 the expected reduction in stroke and mortality at 30 days was not statistically significant and the study is underpowered to exclude an absence of stroke or death reduction. Also the regional anesthetic technique and the LA solution used in GALA was not optimal for all centers and thus may affect the results. According Paraskevas et al 23 the expected stroke and death rates following CEA are so low that it was unlikely that the GALA trial would show any significant difference between LA and GA. Also there was a large difference in shunt usage between the 2 groups. Due to these large differences in shunt usage in GALA trial, a subgroup analysis after adjustment for shunt usage (eg, GA + shunt vs LA + shunt, GA – shunt vs LA – shunt, etc) may produce different results in stroke rates. Another potential variable is the type of shunt. Some atraumatic shunts may be associated with lower perioperative stroke rates. Rerkasem et al 24 established meta-analysis of the GALA trial with the 9 previous smaller randomized control trials and reported that analysis of currently available randomized control trials is underpowered to reliably determine the effect of LA versus GA and more randomized control trials are needed. We can explain the differences between our study and GALA trial by aforementioned articles.

Also, in a more recently published study, Wijeyaratne et al 25 identified that an acute increase in jugular venous neuron nonspecific enolase (NSE) levels is observed after CEA performed under GA but not after CEA performed under LA. As a result of this study, LA may provide some protection against perioperative cerebral injury during CEA. According to this study, peroperative stroke and mortality must be less under LA unlike GALA trial.

Another important point is that pain or anxiety during the CEA under LA may increase the stress and pain, which may result in an increase in the incidence of perioperative MI. But we did not observe any statistical difference at perioperative MI rates (1.2% for GA and 0.5% for LA). We attribute this to premedication and intraoperative sedation and analgesia to minimize this stress and pain.

Long-term restenosis prevalence is important for interpreting the durability of CEA. The reported prevalence of long-term restenosis ranges from 1% to 36%. 19 These differences in prevalence may be due to variations in design of the studies, duration of follow-up periods, criteria used to define restenosis, or methods of arterial closure. The prevalence rates that were reported in major studies published during the last 10 years are presented in Table 3 . We found the restenosis prevalence as 6.66% for patients receiving GA, 5% for patients receiving LA, and 5.75% for all patients. Many factors that affect restenosis development have been identified. Hypertension, hyperlipidemia, not performing patch angioplasty in small internal carotid arteries (internal diameter <4 mm), female gender, smoking, and diabetes have been shown to affect restenosis development. 26
–36 However, we did not find any data regarding the effect of LA on restenosis development. Problems related to consciousness of patients under LA may cause stress in surgeons and lead to unintended short- and long-term consequences In our study, however, no difference was found between patients undergoing CEA under GA and LA, with regard to restenosis development in the short or long term. Moreover, both groups had similar long-term mortality and neurological morbidity rates.

sec.p: In conclusion, LA is safer to use than GA for CEA procedures. It is clear that advantages of LA include availability of testing the consciousness of patients by direct contact, reduced use of shunts, and shorter hospitalization periods. Moreover, the prevalence of permanent stroke encountered in patients undergoing CEA under LA is less in the short term and similar in the long term when compared with those undergoing CEA under GA. It is therefore reasonable to prefer LA for CEA procedures.
